evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim, with no contradictory data undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim data, including timing, crew roles, and situational context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies communication breakdown.
The described behaviors reflect coordination failure rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as the cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication among crew and a lack of warning signals indicating a coordination failure, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown (R2).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or environmental factors contributed more significantly to the event.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim data, including timing, crew roles, and situational context.

assumptions: The described crew roles and interactions reflect typical communication and coordination patterns
No unreported mechanical faults influenced the event
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or procedural adherence without coordination issues
If mechanical faults were identified that better explain the event
If environmental or marking deficiencies were primary causes

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, and H9 directly describe crew communication and coordination roles, timing, and situational context consistent with a communication/coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation without more explicit procedural detail

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim, with no contradictory data undermining this root cause.

assumptions: The absence of reported mechanical faults implies no mechanical control failure.
The described communication failures are representative of the critical coordination breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or timely warnings from the wingman or headset operator that were ignored, or if mechanical faults were identified, this would challenge the communication breakdown explanation.
